title: William and Kate giggle together as they get into tuktuk in new video
text:
The Duke and Duchess of Cambridge have just completed a tour of Pakistan (Picture: Kensington Palace)

Prince William and Kate Middleton were seen sharing a giggle as they climbed into a tuktuk as part of their tour of Pakistan.

New video released by Kensington Palace shows the moment they got into the small vehicle, ready to be taken to a reception celebrating the Commonwealth country’s relationship with the UK.

The specially decorated vehicle had a Pakistani flag next to the Union Jack behind the backseat.

Kate donned a glittering emerald dress designed by Jenny Packham while William wore a sherwani by Karachi-based designer Naushemian.

Kensington Palace shared the video saying simply, ‘Thank you Pakistan!’ in both English and Urdu.

It included clips from the rest of their trip, including the couple visiting a cancer hospital, playing cricket and touring Pakistan’s northern mountains and glaciers.

Kate wore a sparking emerald dress and Prince William a sherwani (Picture: WireImage)

The royal couple were in Pakistan for five days, during which time they dined with the prime minister and made an emotional tour of a cancer hospital previously visited by William’s mother, the late Princess Diana.

While heading home on Friday they were caught up in mid-air drama when their flight home was forced to abort two landing attempts due to bad weather.

Their Royal Air Force Voyager aircraft could not land in the capital, Islamabad and had to return to the eastern city of Lahore, calling off their scheduled visit to the Khyber Pass region bordering Afghanistan.

They had had toured the Shaukat Khanum Memorial Cancer Hospital and Research Centre on Thursday, which was started in the early 1990s by the cricketer-turned-politician Imran Khan, now Pakistan’s prime minister, whose first wife Jemima Goldsmith was a friend of Princess Diana.

They shared a giggle in the tukuk (Picture: Kensington Palace)

Earlier that day, the royal couple played cricket with children and members of Pakistan’s cricket team at the National Cricket Academy.

The royal couple also toured Pakistan’s northern mountains and glaciers Wednesday, getting a look at how the South Asian country is addressing problems related to the climate change crisis.

They met with members of the non-Muslim Kalash community, who presented them with traditional coats, hats and scarves before enjoying performances of traditional dances and music by local residents.

William and Kate are strong advocates of girls’ education, and their first engagement was a visit to a school for girls in the capital, followed by a tour of the nearby national park at Margalla Hills.
